revision.text:
'''Canada-Asia Relations''' are relations between [[Canada]] and [[Asia]]n countries. These include [[Bilateralism|bilateral]] relations between Canada and individual Asian states and [[Multilateralism|multilateral]] relations through groups such as [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]].
==Historical relations==
Canada's relations with Asia stem from their respective colonial pasts, particularly with those countries who are also members of the British [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. This is because until the [[Balfour Declaration of 1926]] Canada's foreign affairs were mainly handled by [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. Canada also shares a colonial past with Asian countries previously under French rule, namely [[Vietnam]], [[Laos]] and [[Cambodia]]. Prior to the establishment of bilateral ties between Asia and Canada, thousands of Chinese and Japanese immigrants arrived in Canada throughout the 19th century.
Direct engagement with Asia began in 1919 with the formation of the [[League of Nations]]. Canada was one of the founding members, which also included the Asian states of [[China]], [[Japan]] and [[Thailand]], then known as [[Siam]].
The [[Chinese Immigration Act, 1923|1923 Chinese Immigration Act]] banned all immigrants from China, except for those with the title of Diplomat, Merchant or Foreign student. The Act was repealed in 1947.
In 1929 Canada opened a legation in [[Tokyo]].
The next significant interaction with Asia was the Canadian's involvement in fighting the Japanese in [[World War II]]. During the War the majority of [[Japanese Canadian internment|Japanese-Canadians were placed in internment camps]] under the [[War Measures Act]].
Canada also partook in the [[Korean War]].
Bilateral diplomatic ties with China were established in 1971, when the two countries exchanged ambassadors. This was followed by a 1973 visit to China by Canadian Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]].
Today, [[Asian Canadian]]s comprise about 11.73% of Canada's total population.<ref>[http://www.asiapacific.ca/statistics/population/population-2006-census/proportion-total-population-major-asian-ethnic-groups-p Proportion of Total Population of Major Asian Ethnic Groups by Province | Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Political relations==
Canada's relations with Asia vary significantly between countries. For example, Canada has taken a number of political and economic measures against [[Burma]], whose military government's policies it believes violate [[human rights]].<ref>[http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/thailand-thailande/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/canada-burma-birmanie.aspx?lang=eng&menu_id=10&menu=L Canada's Policy on Burma<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This is contrasted with warmer ties with countries like [[South Korea]], with whom Canada has relaxed visa, educational and trade policies.<ref>[http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/korea-coree/bilateral_relations_bilaterales/index.aspx?lang=eng Canada - Korea Relations<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
{{main|Canada's role in the invasion of Afghanistan}} Canada is one of 41 countries participating in the [[International Security Assistance Force]] (ISAF) mission in [[Afghanistan]], where Canada has been engaged in Security and Reconstruction efforts since 2002.
Canada provides aid to many Asian countries, with a special focus on [[Afghanistan]], [[Pakistan]], [[Vietnam]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Bangladesh]].<ref>[http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/NIC-5510486-KDG Asia - CIDA<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127172726/http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/NIC-5510486-KDG |date=November 27, 2009 }}</ref>
===Intergovernmental Organizations===
Canada is a member of [[APEC]], an intergovernmental forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, economic growth and development, and cooperation in the Asia–Pacific region.<ref>[http://www.dfait.gc.ca/apec/index.aspx APEC 2010 - Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Canada maintains close ties with the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] through the Joint Cooperation Workplan signed between the two parties.<ref>[http://www.international.gc.ca/asia_pacific-asie_pacifique/asean-anase.aspx?lang=eng Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Canada, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos are all members of la [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie]].
==Economic relations==
Asia's market share (the proportion of Canadian imports) in Canada accounts for 19.2%.<ref>[http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/tdo-dcd.nsf/eng/Home Trade Data Online - Home<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 9.83% of total Canadian imports come from China and 3.53% come from Japan. Canada's market share in Asia is only 0.96%, creating a trade deficit. Due to its proximity to Asia across the [[Pacific]] [[Vancouver]] is the major port for Canada's trade with Asia.<ref>[http://www.asiapacific.ca/sites/default/files/archived_pdf/apbn/bulletin263.pdf Asia's Massive Container Port Development Pressures Canada to Respond - Asia Pacific Bulletin<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This has prompted the Canadian government's [[Asia–Pacific Gateway and Corridor Initiative]].
Canada is currently negotiating [[Free Trade Agreement]]s with [[South Korea]] and [[Singapore]] and is engaged in discussions for a [[Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement between Canada and India|Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement]] with [[India]]. It also has several Foreign Investment Protection and Promotion Agreements with Asian countries.<ref>[http://www.international.gc.ca/trade-agreements-accords-commerciaux/agr-acc/index.aspx Negotiations and Agreements, by Category<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
According to the China Goes Global Survey conducted by the [[Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada]], Canada is poised to accept a greater share of Chinese investment, as Canada is seen by Chinese investors as having one of the most open attitudes to their presence.<ref>[http://www.asiapacific.ca/surveys/chinese-investment-intentions-surveys/china-goes-global-2009 China Goes Global, 2009 | Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Canada-Asia Relations by Country==
* [[Afghanistan–Canada relations]] * [[Canada–China relations]] * [[Canada–India relations]] * [[Canada–Indonesia relations]] * [[Canada–Iran relations]] * [[Canada–Israel relations]] * [[Canada–Japan relations]] * [[Canada–Kazakhstan relations]] * [[Canada–Lebanon relations]] * [[Canada–Malaysia relations]] * [[Canada–Mongolia relations]] * [[Canada–North Korea relations]] * [[Canada–Pakistan relations]] * [[Canada–Saudi Arabia relations]] * [[Canada–Singapore relations]] * [[Canada–South Korea relations]] * [[Canada–Taiwan relations]] * [[Canada–Turkey relations]] * [[Canada–United Arab Emirates relations]]
==References== {{Portal|Asia|Canada|International relations}} {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.international.gc.ca/asia_pacific-asie_pacifique/index.aspx?lang=eng Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade Canada - Asia Pacific Region] *[http://www.asiapacific.ca The Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada]
{{Foreign relations of Canada}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Turkey}} "Bana Bana" | image = | caption = | year = 1989 | country = Turkey | artist = Hazal Selçuk,
Arzu Ece,
Sarper Semiz,
Vedat Sakman | as = Pan | with = | language = Turkish | languages = | composer = [[Timur Selçuk]] | lyricist = [[Timur Selçuk]] | conductor = [[Timur Selçuk]] | place = 21st | points = 5 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1989tr from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Sufi | prev_link = Sufi (song) | next = Gözlerinin Hapsindeyim | next_link = Gözlerinin Hapsindeyim }} '''"Bana Bana"''' ("To me, To me") was the Turkish entry at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1989]], performed by the group Pan. Hazan Selçuk, one of the two soloists of Pan, the other being [[Arzu Ece]], is the daughter of [[Timur Selçuk]],{{cite web | title =Turkey in 1989 | work =Biography | publisher =ESCToday | year =1989 | url =http://www.esctoday.com/annual/1989/page/17 | accessdate =2009-01-06 }} who was the composer and lyricist of the song and the conductor for the entry. The song was performed 5th on the night of the contest, following the Netherlands’ [[Justine Pelmelay]] with "[[Blijf zoals je bent]]" and preceding Belgium’s [[Ingeborg (singer)|Ingeborg]] with "[[Door de wind]]". The song received 5 points, placing 21st in a field of 22. In 1990, it was remixed and released as a hit-single in Sweden. The song was succeeded as Turkish representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1990|1990 contest]] by [[Kayahan Açar|Kayahan]] with "[[Gözlerinin Hapsindeyim]]". ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}}{{succession box | before=[[Sufi (song)|Sufi]] | title=[[Turkey|Turkish]] entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=[[Eurovision Song Contest 1989|1989]] | after=[[Gözlerinin Hapsindeyim]] |}} {{s-end}} {{Turkey in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1989}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Turkey]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1989]] [[Category:Turkish-language songs]] [[Category:1989 songs]] {{turkey-stub}} {{1980s-song-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox document | document_name= Constitution of San Marino | italic_title= no | image= San Marino constitution 1600.jpg | image_width= 230px | image_caption= Illustration of the title page | date_created= October 8, 1600 | date_ratified= | location_of_document= [[San Marino]] | writer= | signers= | purpose= Constitutional statutes | wikisource= }} {{Politics of San Marino}} The '''Constitution of [[San Marino]]''' is distributed over a number of legislative instruments of which the most significant are the Statutes of 1600 and the Declaration of Citizen Rights of 1974 as amended in 2002. The constitutional system has influences from the ''[[Corpus Juris Civilis]]'' and [[Roman law|Roman]] customary law. It may have the [[List of national constitutions|oldest surviving constitution]] of any [[sovereign state]] in the world.<ref name="Slomp2011">{{cite book|author=Slomp, Hans|title=Europe, A Political Profile: An American Companion to European Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LmfAPmwE6YYC&lpg=PA693&ots=SXGYnu2f0V&dq=oldest%20constitution%20Marino&hl=zh-CN&pg=PA693#v=onepage&q=oldest%20constitution%20Marino&f=false|accessdate=6 July 2011|year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-39181-1|page=693}}</ref>
==The Statutes of 1600== The current legal system of [[San Marino]] began on October 8, 1600. The government gave binding force to a compilation of ''Statuti'' written by [[Camillo Bonelli]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Miller |first=William |year=1901 |title=The Republic of San Marino |journal=[[American Historical Review]] |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=633–649 [p. 642] |doi=10.2307/1834173 }}</ref> covering the institutions and practices of Sammarinese government and justice at that time. It was written in Latin and contained in six books. The title in Latin is ''Statuta Decreta ac Ordinamenta Illustris Reipublicae ac Perpetuae Libertatis Terrae Sancti Marini''.
The new system was an update on the ''Statuti Comunali'' (Town Statute) which had served San Marino from about 1300. Existing institutions, such as the [[Grand and General Council|Council of the Sixty]], were carried forward from this period. The Statutes form the basis of all law in effect today, so it may be the oldest constitution of any existing nation.
=== Book One === The first book contains 62 articles. It is constitutional in character and describes the various [[Grand and General Council|councils]] of San Marino, [[court]]s, a number of administrative positions, including the [[Captains-Regent]], and the powers assigned to them. The last two articles explain how the law is to be interpreted and altered, including how the law is to be [[Promulgation|promulgated]].
=== Book Two === The second book, called ''Civilium Causarum'', contains 75 articles. The first half provides for [[Corpus Juris Civilis|civil law]] procedures covering [[subpoena]]s, [[Evidence (law)|evidence]], examination of [[witness]]es and judicial expenses. The second half covers [[Minor (law)|minors]], [[education]], the salaries of the [[civil service]] and [[will (law)|wills]]. There is a section which promotes [[compromise]] to resolve disputes and another which regulates the [[salary]] of [[lawyer]]s.
=== Book Three === The third book, called ''Maleficiorum'', contains 74 articles and covers [[criminal law]]. [[prosecutor|Prosecution]] of criminal acts is reserved for the [[Sovereign state|state]] alone. The laws provide a formula by which a [[punishment]] shall be proportional to the [[Offense (law)|offense]] and any [[mitigating circumstance]]s. Special attention is given to protecting the assets of the state and [[Roman Catholic Church|church]], and to preventing the [[pollution]] of [[water]] sources.
=== Book Four === The fourth book, called ''De Appellationibus'', contains 15 articles. The volume explains how [[judge]]s are nominated, the classification of [[Sentence (law)|sentences]], [[appeal]]s and [[appellant]] guarantees.
=== Book Five === The fifth book, called ''Extraordinarium'', contains 46 articles covering a range of topics. These include the sale of [[meat]], [[sanitation]] and [[health]], [[water]] reserves and [[road]]s.
=== Book Six === The sixth book contains 42 articles and covers [[Damages|compensation]], [[weight]]s and [[Tillage|plant cultivation]]. In particular, it explains that [[Pater familias|family heads]] are responsible for the actions of their sons and any [[servant]]s.
==Declaration of Citizen Rights== On 12 July 1974 the [[Captains-Regent]] signed a law (59/1974) adopted by the [[Grand and General Council]] containing a declaration of citizen rights and the fundamental principles of the juridical order of San Marino. The Declaration begins with a repudiation of [[war]]. It states the people are [[sovereignty|sovereign]] and explains how the [[separation of powers]] doctrine is applicable to San Marino. Citizens are guaranteed certain rights including [[Equality before the law|equality]], [[inviolability]], [[Freedom (political)|freedom]], and universal [[suffrage]].
Jorri Duursma describes the 1974 law as the fundamental law of the Republic.<ref name="Duursma1996">{{cite book|author=Jorri Duursma|title=Fragmentation and the international relations of micro-states: self-determination and statehood|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CgVDprXjkIYC&pg=PA211|accessdate=6 July 2011|year=1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-56360-4|page=211}}</ref>
The Declaration was amended in 2002, providing further constitutional detail on the organisation of government and establishing the [[Guarantors’ Panel on the Constitutionality of Rules]], which is a court responsible for assessing the compliance of laws with respect to the Declaration of Rights.
== See also == {{Portal|Europe|Law}} * [[History of San Marino]] * [[Politics of San Marino]] * [[List of national constitutions]] * [[Guarantors’ Panel on the Constitutionality of Rules]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929001535/http://www2.omniway.sm/sanmarinoguide/aboutsanmarino/sanmarinoguide_get_par.php3?PARAM=29 Leges Statutae Republicae Sancti Marini] ''in Italian'', archived from [http://www2.omniway.sm/sanmarinoguide/aboutsanmarino/sanmarinoguide_get_par.php3?PARAM=29 the original] 29 September 2007 * ''Per Conoscere San Marino'', Dicastero P.I. e C., Scuola Media Statale, 1991
{{San Marino topics}} {{Constitution of Europe}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Constitution Of San Marino}} [[Category:1600 in law]] [[Category:Constitutions by country|San Marino]] [[Category:Sammarinese law]]
{{SanMarino-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Court of Labour''' ({{lang-nl|Arbeidshof}}, {{lang-fr|Cour du travail}}, {{lang-de|Arbeitsgerichtshof}}) in [[Belgium]] is a [[court]] which hears appeals against decisions of the [[Labour Court (Belgium)|Labour Court]] ({{lang-nl|Arbeidsrechtbank}}, {{lang-fr|Tribunal du travail}}, {{lang-de|Arbeitsgericht}}). There are five Courts of Labour in Belgium: in [[Antwerp (city)|Antwerp]], [[Brussels]], [[Ghent]], [[Liège (city)|Liège]] and [[Mons]]. Their territorial jurisdictions are the same as those of the [[Court of Appeal (Belgium)|Courts of Appeal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pers-gerecht.be/document.php?document_id=96&lang=nl |title=Arbeidshof |publisher=[http://www.pers-gerecht.be/ Pers & Gerecht] |accessdate=2007-07-10 |language=Dutch }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pers-gerecht.be/document.php?document_id=96&lang=fr |title=La cour du travail |publisher=[http://www.presse-justice.be/ Presse & Justice] |accessdate=2007-07-10 |language=French }}</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Belgian labour law]] [[Category:Judiciary of Belgium|Labour, Court of]] [[Category:Labour courts]]

{{ethnic group |group=Ghomara |population = 1 million |popplace=Western [[Rif]], [[Morocco]] |rels=[[Islam]] |langs=[[Ghomara language|Ghomara]], [[Jebli Arabic]] |related=Other [[Berbers]], [[Jebala people]] }} [[File:Pays-Ghomara.PNG|thumb|Map of the Ghomara tribes and their territories<ref>A. Zouggari & J. Vignet-Zunz, "Jbala: Histoire et société", in ''Sciences Humaines'', (1991), p.463. ({{ISBN|2-222-04574-6}})</ref>]] The '''Ghomara''' are an ethnic group of northern [[Morocco]], living between the rivers [[Oued Laou]] and [[Ouringa]], east of [[Chefchaouen]] and south of [[Tetouan]], in the Western [[Rif]]. The river [[Tiguisas]] runs through their territory.<ref name="EB" />
Originally, Ghomaras are a [[Berbers|Berber]] tribal group belonging to the [[Masmuda|Masmouda]] confederacy. While most have shifted to speaking [[Arabic language|Arabic]], a minority continue to speak the [[Berber languages|Berber]] [[Ghomara language]].<ref name="EB" />
== Tribes == The Ghomaras are traditionally divided into eight tribes: * Beni Ziat * Beni Zejel * Beni Selman * Beni Bu Zra, partially [[Ghomara language|Berber speaking]] tribe<ref name="EB">G. Camps & J. Vignet-Zunz, "Ghomâra", in ''Encyclopédie berbère, vol.20'', 1998</ref> * Beni Mansur, partially [[Ghomara language|Berber speaking]] tribe<ref name="EB" /> * Beni Grir * Beni Smih * Beni Rezin * Beni Khaled
==Bibliography== * G. Camps & J. Vignet-Zunz, « [http://encyclopedieberbere.revues.org/1923 Ghomâra] », ''Encyclopédie berbère, vol.20'', 1998, pp. 3110–3119 * Jamal el Hannouche, "[https://www.scribd.com/doc/46039741/Arabic-Influence-in-Ghomara-Berber-by-J-El-Hannouche Arabic influence in Ghomara Berber]", Leiden University, 2010. * Jamal el Hannouche, "[https://www.scribd.com/doc/46042206/Ghomara-Berber-a-Brief-Grammatical-Survey-by-J-El-Hannouche Ghomara Berber, a brief grammatical survey]", Leiden University, 2008. * Peter Behnstedt, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20131029192101/http://www.ieiop.csic.es/pub/02behnstedt_fcb02593.pdf La frontera entre el bereber y el árabe en el Rif]", ''Estudios de dialectología norteafricana y andalusí'' vol. 6, 2002. * Georges Séraphin Colin, "Le parler berbère des Ghomara", ''Hesperis'' 9, 1929, pp. 43–58.
==References== <references /> {{Berber tribes of Morocco}} {{Ethnic groups in Morocco}} {{Berber}}
[[Category:Arabized Berbers]] [[Category:Berber peoples and tribes]] [[Category:Rif]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Morocco]] [[Category:Berbers in Morocco]]

revision.text:
'''Grotulja''' is a sort of [[necklace]] made out of [[walnuts]] lined on string. Grotulja is a symbol of area around [[Trilj]] town in [[Croatia]]. Traditionally it was given by a young man to a girl on a feast of [[Saint Michael]] (patron saint of Trilj) as a symbol of affection or even as symbol of marriage proposal.
==Sources== * [http://www.dalmatia.hr/en/culture-and-sights/trilj-grotulja Trilj - Grotulja]
[[Category:Croatian folklore]] [[Category:Necklaces]]

Stano Simor | lyricist = [[Gordon Pogoda]] | place = | points = | place_semi = 18th | points_semi = 9 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?2008cz from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Malá Dáma | prev_link = Malá dáma | next = Aven Romale | next_link = Aven Romale }} '''"Have Some Fun"''' is the [[Czech Republic|Czech Republic's]] entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008]] and was chosen to represent them on 26 January 2008. The song is sung by [[Tereza Kerndlová]] and was performed in the 2nd place on the national final. This song was the second Czech entry for Eurovision, and Tereza Kerndlová performed the song in the second semi-final, on 22 May 2008. The song was written by [[Gordon Pogoda]] and Stano Simor. It failed to secure a place in the final. Despite only garnering nine points, it was the Czech Republic's most successful entry until [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] when the Czech Republic qualified to the final for the first time. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !align="left"|Chart (2008) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|[[Czech Republic|Czech Republic IFPI Singles Chart]][http://www.ifpicr.cz/hitparada/index.php?a=titul&hitparada=2&titul=145296&sec=7a99ea8978e8f1fb1e29520427a39a28 Czech Republic Airplay Chart] |align="center"|5 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Czech Republic in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2008}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2008]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of the Czech Republic]] [[Category:2008 songs]] {{2000s-song-stub}} {{CzechRepublic-stub}}

page.title: International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Health standards]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health''' ('''ICF''') is a [[medical classification|classification]] of the health components of functioning and disability. {{Disability}}
The ICF received approval from all 191 [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) member states on May 22, 2001, during the 54th [[World Health Assembly]].<ref name=WHO_ICF>{{cite web |date=22 July 2016 |title=International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) |website=World Health Organization |url=http://www.who.int/classifications/icf/en/ }}</ref> Its approval followed nine years of international revision efforts coordinated by WHO.<ref name=CDC_ICF/> WHO's initial classification for the effects of diseases, the ''International Classification of Impairments, Disabilities, and Handicaps'' (ICIDH), was created in 1980.<ref name=CDC_ICF>{{cite web|date=24 January 2008 |title=International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) |website=National Center for Health Statistics |url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/about/otheract/icd9/icfhome.htm |archive-date=10 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090510090103/http://www.cdc.gov/NCHS/about/otheract/icd9/icfhome.htm |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The ICF classification complements WHO's [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems|International Classification of Diseases]]-10th Revision (ICD), which contains information on diagnosis and health condition, but not on functional status. The ICD and ICF constitute the core classifications in the [[WHO Family of International Classifications]] (WHO-FIC).<ref name=beginnerICF>{{citation |title=Towards a Common Language for Functioning, Disability and Health: ICF |date=2002 |publisher=World Health Organization |location=Geneva |url=http://www.who.int/entity/classifications/icf/icfbeginnersguide.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>{{rp|3-4}}
==Overview== The ICF is structured around the following broad components:
* Body functions and structure * Activities (related to tasks and actions by an individual) and participation (involvement in a life situation) * Additional information on severity and environmental factors
Functioning and disability are viewed as a complex interaction between the health condition of the individual and the contextual factors of the environment as well as personal factors. The picture produced by this combination of factors and dimensions is of "the person in his or her world". The classification treats these dimensions as interactive and dynamic rather than linear or static. It allows for an assessment of the degree of disability, although it is not a measurement instrument. It is applicable to all people, whatever their health condition. The language of the ICF is neutral as to etiology, placing the emphasis on function rather than condition or disease. It also is carefully designed to be relevant across cultures as well as age groups and genders, making it highly appropriate for heterogeneous populations.
== Benefits == There are benefits of using the ICF for both the patient and the health professional. A major advantage for the patient is the integration of the physical, mental, and social aspects of his or her health condition. All aspects of a person’s life (development, participation and environment) are incorporated into the ICF instead of solely focusing on his or her diagnosis. A diagnosis reveals little about one’s functional abilities. Diagnoses are important for defining the cause and prognosis, but identifying the limitations of function is often the information used to plan and implement interventions.<ref name="Lollar">{{cite journal |last1=Lollar |first1=Donald J. |last2=Simeonsson |first2=Rune J. |date=August 2005 |title=Diagnosis to function: classification for children and youths |journal=Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=323-330 |doi=10.1097/00004703-200508000-00012 }}</ref> Once a rehabilitation team is aware of the daily activities a client is required to participate in, the problem solving sequence set up by the ICF can be utilized. An occupational therapist, for example, would observe a patient performing his or her daily activities and note the patient's functional abilities. This information would then be used to determine the extent to which the individual’s abilities can be improved through therapy and to what extent the environment can be changed to facilitate the individual's performance.<ref name="Bornman">{{cite journal |last=Bornman |first=J. |date=4 February 2004 |title=The World Health Organization’s terminology and classification: application to severe disability |journal=Disability and Rehabilitation |volume=26 |issue=3 |pages=182-188 |doi=10.1080/09595230020029365 |pmid=14754630 }}</ref> Intervention at one level (current abilities) has the potential to prevent or modify events at a succeeding level (participation). For example, teaching a deaf child manual signs will foster effective interaction and increase one’s participation with his or her family.<ref name="Bornman" />
Rehabilitation therapists will be empowered with the ICF not only in their daily work with their patients, but also when working with other medical disciplines; hospitals and other health care administrations; health authorities and policy makers.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Stucki |first1=G. |last2=Ewert |first2=T. |last3=Cieza |first3=A. |date=20 November 2002 |title=Value and application of the ICF in rehabilitation medicine |journal=Disability and Rehabilitation |volume=24 |issue=17 |pages=932-938 |doi=10.1080/09638280210148594 |pmid=12523361 }}</ref> All items are operationally defined with clear descriptions that can be applied to real life evaluations with clarity and ease.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Üstün |first1=T.B. |last2=Chatterji |first2=S. |last3=Bickenbach |first3=J. |last4=Kostanjsek |first4=N. |last5=Schneider |first5=M. |date=3 June 2003 |title=The International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health: A new tool for understanding disability and health |journal=Disability and Rehabilitation |volume=25 |issue=11-12 |pages=565–571 |doi=10.1080/0963828031000137063 |pmid=12959329 }}</ref> The language used in the ICF helps facilitate better communication between these groups of people.
== Clinical relevance == Knowing how a disease affects one’s functioning enables better planning of services, treatment, and rehabilitation for persons with long-term disabilities or chronic conditions. The current ICF creates a more integrative understanding of health forming a comprehensive profile of an individual instead of focusing on one’s disease, illness, or disability.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hemmingsson |first1=Helena |last2=Jonsson |first2=Hans |date=September 2005 |title=An occupational perspective on the concept of participation in the international classification of functioning, disability and health – some critical remarks |journal=The American Journal of Occupational Therapy |volume=59 |issue=5 |pages=569-576 |doi=10.5014/ajot.59.5.569 |url=http://ajot.aota.org/article.aspx?articleid=1872109 }}</ref> The implications of using the ICF include an emphasis on the strengths of individuals, assisting individuals in participating more extensively in society by the use of interventions aimed at enhancing their abilities, and taking into consideration the environmental and personal factors that might hamper their participation.<ref name="Bornman" /> Qualifiers: The ICF qualifiers “may be best translated clinically as the levels of functioning seen in a standardized or clinic setting and in everyday environments”.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reed |first1=Geoffrey M. |last2=Lux |first2=Jayne B. |last3=Bufka |first3=Lynn F. |last4=Trask |first4=Christine |last5=Peterson |first5=David B. |last6=Stark |first6=Susan |last7=Threats |first7=Travis T. |last8=Jacobson |first8=John W. |last9=Hawley |first9=Judy A. |date=May 2005 |title=Operationalizing the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health in Clinical Settings |journal=Rehabilitation Psychology |volume=50 |issue=2 |pages=122-131 |url=https://www.academia.edu/download/39734204/Reed_Article_48__Reed_et_al_Rehab_Psych_2005.pdf |format=PDF |doi=10.1037/0090-5550.50.2.122 |quote=The Capacity and Performance qualifiers as outlined in the ICF Activities and Participation section may be best translated clinically as the levels of functioning seen in a standardized or clinic setting (Capacity) and in everyday environments (Performance). }}</ref> Qualifiers support standardization and the understanding of functioning in a multidisciplinary assessment. They enable all team members to quantify the extent of problems, even in areas of functioning where one is not a specialist.<ref name="Rauch">{{cite journal |last1=Rauch |first1=A. |last2=Cieza |first2=A. |last3=Stucki |first3=G. |date=September 2008 |title=How to apply the International Classification of Functioning Disability and Health (ICF) for rehabilitation management in clinical practice |journal=European Journal of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine |volume=44 |issue=3 |pages=329-342 |pmid=18762742 |url=http://www.minervamedica.it/en/journals/europa-medicophysica/article.php?cod=R33Y2008N03A0329 }}</ref> Without qualifiers codes have no inherent meaning. An impairment, limitation or restriction, is qualified from 0 (No problem; 0-4%), 1 (Mild problem: 5-24%), 2 (Moderate problem: 25-49%), 3 (Severe problem: 50-95%) to 4 (Complete problem: 96-100%). Environmental factors are quantified with a negative and positive scale denoting the extent to which the environment acts as a barrier or facilitator.<ref>World Health Organization. (2001). International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF). Geneva: Author.</ref> For insurance purposes, the qualifiers can describe the effectiveness of treatment. One can interpret the decreasing of a qualifier score to be an increase in the functional ability of a patient.
== Core sets == An ICF Core Set can serve as a reference framework and a practical tool to classify and describe patient functioning in a more time efficient way. ICF Core Sets can be used along the continuum of care and over the course of a health condition.<ref name="Rauch" /> The ICF classification includes more than 1,400 categories limiting its use in clinical practice.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Arlinger |first1=M. |last2=Stamm |first2=T.A. |last3=Pisetsky |first3=D.S. |last4=Yarboro |first4=C.H. |last5=Cieza |first5=A. |last6=Smolen |first6=J.S. |last7=Stucki |first7=G. |date=April 2006 |title=ICF core sets: how to specify impairment and function in systemic lupus erythematosus |journal=Lupus |volume=15 |issue=4 |pages=248-253 |doi=10.1191/0961203306lu2298xx |pmid=16686267 }}</ref> It is time consuming for a clinician to utilize the main volume of the ICF with his or her patients. Only a fraction of the categories is needed. As a general rule, 20% of the codes will explain 80% of the variance observed in practice.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ustün |first1=B. |last2=Chatterji |first2=S. |last3=Kostanjsek |first3=N. |date=July 2004 |title=Comments from WHO for the Journal of Rehabilitation Medicine special supplement on ICF core sets |journal=Journal of Rehabilitation Medicine |issue=Suppl. 44 |pages=7-8 |doi=10.1080/16501960410015344 |pmid=15370741 |url=http://www.medicaljournals.se/jrm/content/?doi=10.1080/16501960410015344 }}</ref> ICF Core Sets contain as few as possible, but as many ICF categories as necessary, to describe a patient’s level of functioning.<ref name="Rauch" /> It is hypothesized that using an ICF Core Set will increase the inter-rater reliability when coding clinical cases as only the relevant categories for a particular patient will be utilized. Since all of the relevant categories are listed in an ICF Core Set, its use in multidisciplinary assessments protects health professionals from missing important aspects of functioning.<ref name="Rauch" />
== Pediatric use == As clinicians and researchers used the ICF, they became more aware of its limitations. The ICF lacks the ability to classify the functional characteristics of a developing child. Different ICF codes are needed across the first years of a child’s life to capture the growth and development of a disability even when the child's diagnosis does not change.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Simeonsson |first1=R.J. |last2=Scarborough |first2=A.A. |last3=Hebbeler |first3=K.M. |date=April 2006 |title=ICF and ICD codes provide a standard language of disability in young children |journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology |volume=59 |issue=4 |pages=365-373 |doi=10.1016/j.jclinepi.2005.09.009 |pmid=16549258 }}</ref> The coding system can provide essential information about the severity of a health condition in terms of its impact on functioning. This can serve a significant role for providers caring for children with spectrum disorders such as autism or cerebral palsy.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ogonowski |first1=J. |last2=Kronk |first2=R. |last3=Rice |first3=C. |last4=Feldman |first4=H. |date=18 March 2004 |title=Inter-rater reliability in assigning ICF codes to children with disabilities |journal=Disability and Rehabilitation |volume=26 |issue=6 |pages=353-361 |doi=10.1080/09638280410001658658 |pmid=15204487 }}</ref> Children with these conditions may have the same diagnoses, but their abilities and levels of functioning widely vary across and within individuals over time. The first draft of the ''International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health for Children and Youth'' (ICF-CY) was completed in year 2003 and published in 2007. The ICF-CY was developed to be structurally consistent with the ICF for adults. A major difference between the ICF-CY and ICF is that the generic qualifiers from the adult ICF now include developmental aspects for children and youth in the ICF-CY. Descriptions of codes in the ICF-CY were revised and expanded and new content was added to previously unused codes. Codes were added to document characteristics as adaptability, responsivity, predictability, persistence, and approachability. “Sensing” and “exploration of objects” codes were expanded as well as the “importance of learning”.<ref name="Lollar" /> Since a child’s main occupation is playing, it is also important to include more codes in this area. Different levels of play have separate codes in the ICF-CY (solitary, onlooker, parallel). This contrasts with the adult ICF as only one code existed in regards to leisure or recreation.
Changes in ICF-CY codes over time reflect developmental effects attributable to the child’s interaction with the environment. Environmental factors influence functioning and development and can be documented as barriers or facilitators using the ICF-CY. The key environments of children and adolescents include their homes, day care centers, schools and recreation settings of playground, parks, and ball fields.<ref name="Simeonsson">{{cite journal |last1=Simeonsson |first1=Rune J. |last2=Lollar |first2=Donald |last3=Hollowell |first3=Joseph |last4=Adams |first4=Mike |date=February 2000 |title=Revision of the international classification of impairments, disabilities, and handicaps: Developmental issues |journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=113-124 |doi=10.1016/S0895-4356(99)00133-X |pmid=10729683 }}</ref> Children will transition between different environments many times as they grow. For example, a child will transition into elementary or high school or from one service setting or agency to another. Attention to these transitions of children with disabilities has been identified as an important role for health care providers.<ref name="Simeonsson" /> A transition requires preparation and planning to find an appropriate and accommodating setting for a child’s needs. With a coding system such as the ICF-CY, the transition will be smoother and interventions can start where the previous health provider left off.
== See also == * [[Social model of disability]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{cite journal |last1=Rosenbaum |first1=Peter |last2=Stewart |first2=Debra |date=March 2004 |title=The world health organization international classification of functioning, disability, and health: a model to guide clinical thinking, practice and research in the field of cerebral palsy |journal=Seminars in Pediatric Neurology |volume=11 |issue=1 |pages=5-10 |doi=10.1016/j.spen.2004.01.002 |pmid=15132248 |url=https://www.academia.edu/download/45166556/The_World_Health_Organization_Internatio20160428-10749-yv0szj.pdf |format=PDF }} * {{citation |title=How to use the ICF: A practical manual for using the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) |edition=Draft |date=October 2013 |publisher=World Health Organization |location=Geneva |url=http://www.who.int/entity/classifications/drafticfpracticalmanual2.pdf?ua=1 |format=PDF |postscript=. }}
== External links == * {{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/classifications/icf/en/ |title=International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) |website=[[World Health Organization]] }} * {{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/icd/icf.htm |title=International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) |website=National Center for Health Statistics |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] }} * {{cite web |url=http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/ICF |title=International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health |publisher=[[National Center for Biomedical Ontology]] |website=BioPortal }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.icf-casestudies.org |title=ICF Case Studies: Translating Interventions into Real-life Gains – a Rehab-Cycle Approach |publisher=Swiss Paraplegic Research }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.reteclassificazioni.it |title=Portale Italiano delle Classificazioni Sanitarie |trans-title=Italian Portal of Health Classifications |publisher= Direzione centrale salute, integrazione sociosanitaria, politiche sociali e famiglia |language=Italian }} The ICF and ICF-CY browsing tool of the Italian Collaborating Centre of the World Health Organization for the Family of International Classifications.

The '''Judiciary of Kiribati''' is the branch of the Government of [[Kiribati]] which interprets and applies the [[law]]s of the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthgovernance.org/countries/pacific/kiribati/judicial-system/|title=The Judicial System of Kiribati|publisher= Commonwealth Governance|accessdate= 20 February 2016}}</ref> In addition to the Constitution, the laws of Kiribati include [[customary law]], which the courts must take into account when considering specified matters in criminal and civil proceedings.
Some 20 [[Magistrates' court|Magistrates Courts]], composed of seven Magistrates and a [[clerk of court|clerk]], deal with less-serious [[civil lawsuit|civil]], [[criminal case|criminal]], and land cases on a district basis.
The High Court hears more serious civil and criminal cases referred to it by the Magistrates Courts, and also hears [[appeal]]s from the lower court. Appeals relating to land, [[divorce]], and [[inheritance]] are dealt with by the High Court's Land Division. Prior to 2014 there was only the one High Court judge, but in that year a second [[puisne judge|(puisne)]] judge was appointed. The Chief Justice of Kiribati|Chief Justice of the High Court is the Head of the Judiciary in Kiribati.
Appeals from the High Court are heard by the Court of Appeal. There are presently (2015) five Judges appointed to the Court of Appeal.
The [[President of Kiribati|president]] is responsible for all judicial appointments.
==Chief Justices== Gilbert Islands * 1977–1981 James Aiden O'Brien Quinn <ref>The International Who's Who 2004</ref>
Kiribati (from 1979) * 1995–2000 [[Richard Lussick]] * 2000-2011 [[Robin Millhouse|Robin Rhodes Millhouse]] (also [[Chief Justice of Nauru]], 2006-2010) * 2011– Sir [[John Muria|John Baptist Muria]]
==References== *{{cite web|url=http://www.paclii.org/ki/court-annual-reports/Chief-justice-address-2015.html|title=Annual Address, 2015|publisher= Chief Justice's Chambers, Kiribati|accessdate= 20 February 2016}} {{reflist}}

/* Notable Macedonians from France */
revision.text:
{{infobox ethnic group| |group= Macedonians in France
Македонци во Франција
''Macédoniens en France'' |population= 2,300[http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/pays-zones-geo_833/macedoine-arym_442/presentation-macedoine-arym_991/donnees-generales_12144.html French Ministry of Foreign Affairs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006102733/http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/pays-zones-geo_833/macedoine-arym_442/presentation-macedoine-arym_991/donnees-generales_12144.html |date=2014-10-06 }}-15,000 (est)[http://www.macedonianhr.org.au/ Official Macedonian Human Rights Website - Australia] |popplace= [[Paris]] |rels=[[Macedonian Orthodox Church|Macedonian Orthodox]] |langs=Primarily [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]] and [[French language|French]] |related-c=[[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonians]] }} {{Ethnic Macedonians}} '''[[Macedonians (ethnic group)|Macedonians]]''' (in {{lang-fr|Macédoniens}}) in [[France]] form a small minority mainly concentrated in the capital [[Paris]]. Many of them were unskilled immigrants and returned to [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] after finishing their work in France.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} After [[World War II]] many returned this time as immigrants.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} Most of the immigrants originated from the [[Struga]], [[Ohrid]] and [[Kicevo]] regions.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} They were primarily settled in migrant hostels and "ghettoes".{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} More still emigrated to France after the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]]. The French government estimates the number of Macedonians in France to be 2,300 while Macedonian figures put the number at over 15,000 people. ==Notable Macedonians from France== *[[:fr:Evdokija Danajlovska]] - composer *[[:fr:Hristijan Šanev]] - painter from Paris *[[:fr:Blagoja Dimčevski]] - violinist from Toulouse{{cite book|last=Shupo|first=Sokol |title=Art music in the Balkans -Documentation and Communication Center for Regional Music|year=2004|publisher=ASMUS}} *[[:fr:Goce Cvetanovski]] -film director/producer from Paris *[[:fr:Stefani Sen Senar]] - writer from Paris{{cite web|url=http://www.bibliomonde.com/auteur/stefani-sen-senar-1778.html|title=Stefani Sen Senar|publisher=Biblio Monde|language=french|accessdate=7 September 2010}} *[[:fr:Zilber Karevski]] - writer{{cite web|url=http://motcomptedouble.blog.lemonde.fr/2006/10/24/2006_10_un_mot_sur_zilb/|title=Un mot sur Zilber Karevski|publisher=Motcomptedouble|language=french|accessdate=24 October 2006}} *[[:fr:Christophe Najdovski]] - politician ==References== {{reflist}} {{Macedonian Diaspora}} {{Migration to France from Europe}} [[Category:European diaspora in France]] [[Category:Ethnic Macedonian minorities]] [[Category:Macedonian diaspora|France]] {{Europe-ethno-group-stub}}

revision.comment: French correction : A "prefecture" is a place, A "prefet" is a man
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{French Navy}} The '''Préfet Maritime''' is a servant of the [[France|French State]] who exercises authority over the sea in one particular region (a ''Préfecture maritime''). As a [[civil servant (France)|civil servant]], he reports to the [[Prime Minister (France)|Prime Minister]]. But the Maritime Prefect is simultaneously charged of military operations, and for this reason also reports to the chief of the general staff ([[Chief of the Defence Staff (France)|CEMA]], or ''Chef d'état-major des armées'').
The dignity was created in 1800 to unify the command of harbours (civil administrator) and the command of the Navy (Admiral).
The ''préfet maritime'' is in charge of the French sovereignty at sea, monitoring operation, safety of the users, police and rescue operations, etc. He also commands all armed vessel linked to his place.
The present ''Préfets maritimes'' are: * [[Mediterranean Fleet (France)|Mediterranean Sea]] ([[Toulon]]): Admiral [[Yann Tainguy]] * [[English Channel]] and [[North Sea]] ([[Cherbourg]]): [[Emmanuel Carlier]] * [[Atlantic]] ([[Château de Brest]], [[Brest, France|Brest]]): [[Emmanuel de Oliveira]] <gallery> Image:Dumontet-Guillaud-Magne.jpg|From left to right: ''Capitaine de Vaisseau'' [[Xavier Magne]] (captain of the ''[[FS Charles de Gaulle|Charles De Gaulle]]''), ''[[vice-amiral d'escadre]]'' Alain Dumontet, commander of the [[Force d'Action Navale]], and ''contre-amiral'' [[Édouard Guillaud]], [[Préfet maritime]] of the English Channel and North Sea (former captain of the ''Charles De Gaulle'' 1999-2001). File:Benoit Chomel de Jarnieu-IMG 9259b.jpg|Admiral [[Yann Tainguy]], Maritime prefect for the Mediterranean </gallery>
==See also== *[[Prefects (France)]]
[[Category:French civil servants]] [[Category:French Navy]] [[Category:Admirals of France]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = Michael Burawoy.jpg | name = Michael Burawoy |birth_date = 15 June 1947 |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = English, American |education = [[University of Cambridge]] (BA)
[[University of Zambia]] (MA)
[[University of Chicago]] (PhD) |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Politics of production]]
[[Factory regime]]
[[Hegemonic despotism]]
[[Extended case method]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |prizes = |footnotes = }} '''Michael Burawoy''' (born 15 June 1947) is a British [[Sociology|sociologist]] working within [[Marxism|Marxist]] social theory, best known as author of ''[[Manufacturing Consent: Changes in the Labor Process under Monopoly Capitalism]]''—a study on work and organizations that has been translated into a number of languages, and the leading proponent of [[public sociology]]. Burawoy was also president of the [[American Sociological Association]] in 2004 and is a professor at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. In 2006–2010, he was vice-president for the Committee of National Associations of the [[International Sociological Association]] (ISA). In the XVII ISA World Congress of Sociology he was elected President of the International Sociological Association (ISA) for the period 2010–2014. ==Biography== Graduating as a mathematics student from the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1968, Burawoy went on to pursue post-graduate study in the newly independent African nation of [[Zambia]], while simultaneously working as a researcher for [[Anglo American PLC]]. Completing a [[Masters degree|master's degree]] at the [[University of Zambia]] in 1972, Burawoy enrolled as a doctoral student at the [[University of Chicago]], finishing a sociology dissertation with an ethnography of Chicago industrial workers, later to become ''[[Manufacturing Consent: Changes in the Labor Process under Monopoly Capitalism]]''. Aside from Burawoy's sociological study of the industrial workplace in Zambia, Burawoy has studied industrial workplaces in [[Chicago]], [[Hungary]], and post-Soviet [[Russia]]. His method of choice is usually [[participant observation]], more specifically [[ethnography]].See his collaborative work on: ''Ethnography Unbound: Power and Resistance in the Modern Metropolis'' (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1991) and ''Global Ethnography: Forces, Connections and Imaginations in a Postmodern World'' (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2000). Based on his studies of the workplace he has looked into the nature of [[postcolonialism]], the organization of [[state socialism]], and the problems in the transition from [[socialism]]. In more recent times, Burawoy has moved away from observing factories to looking at his own place of work—the university—to consider the way sociology is taught to students and how it is put into the [[public domain]]. His work on [[public sociology]] is most prominently shown in his presidential address to the American Sociological Association in 2004, where he divides sociology into four separate (yet overlapping) categories: public sociology, [[policy sociology]] (which has an extra-academic audience), professional sociology (which addresses an academic audience familiar with theoretical and methodological frameworks common to the discipline of sociology), and lastly [[critical sociology]] which, like public sociology, produces reflexive knowledge but which is only available to an academic audience, like professional sociology. ==Selected works== ===Books=== ====Author (or co-author)==== * ''The Colour of Class on the Copper Mines: From African Advancement to Zambianization''. Manchester: Manchester University Press, 1972 * ''[[Manufacturing Consent: Changes in the Labor Process under Monopoly Capitalism]]''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1979 * ''The Politics of Production: Factory Regimes Under Capitalism and Socialism''. London: Verso, 1985 * ''The Radiant Past: Ideology and Reality in Hungary's Road to Capitalism''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1992 (With [[János Lukács]]) * ''The Extended Case Method: Four Countries, Four Decades, Four Great Transformations, and One Theoretical Tradition'' (University of California Press), 2009 ====Collaborative and edited books==== * ''Marxist Inquiries: Studies of Labor, Class and States''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. Supplement to the American Journal of Sociology. Edited with [[Theda Skocpol]], 1983 * ''Ethnography Unbound: Power and Resistance in the Modern Metropolis''. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1991 (With ten coauthors) * ''Uncertain Transition: Ethnographies of Change in the PostSocialist World''. Lanham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield. Edited with [[Katherine Verdery]], 1998 * ''От Деревянного Парижа к Панельной Орбите: Модель жилищных классов Сыктывкара''. (''From Timbered Paris to Concrete Orbita: The Structure of Housing Classes in Syktyvkar''). Syktyvkar: Institute of Regional Social Research of Komi, 1999 (With [[Pavel Krotov]] and [[Tatyana Lytkina]]) * ''Global Ethnography: Forces, Connections and Imaginations in a Postmodern World''. Berkeley: University of California Press, 2000 (With nine coauthors) ===Articles=== * "Dwelling in Capitalism, Traveling Through Socialism.]" pp. 21–44 in Baldoz et al. (editors), ''The Critical Study of Work'' (Philadelphia: Temple University Press.) * {{Cite journal | title = Neoclassical Sociology: From the End of Communism to the End of Classes | journal = [[American Journal of Sociology]] | volume = 106 | issue = 4 | pages = 1099–1120 | publisher = [[Chicago University Press|Chicago Journals]] | doi = 10.1086/320299 | date = January 2001 | url = https://doi.org/10.1086/320299 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/Russia/neoclassical.pdf Pdf.] * "What Happened to the Working Class?" pp. 69–76 in Kevin Leicht (ed.), The Future of the Market transition (New York: JAI Press), 2002 * "Sociological Marxism." pp. 459–86 in Jonathan Turner (ed.), ''The Handbook of Sociological Theory'', 2002 (Plenum Books) (With Erik Wright) * {{Cite journal | title = For a Sociological Marxism: The Complementary Convergence of Antonio Gramsci and Karl Polanyi | journal = [[Politics and Society]] | volume = 31 | issue = 2 | pages = 193–261 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0032329203252270 | date = June 2003 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/0032329203252270 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://ecsocman.hse.ru/data/866/118/1231/Sociological_Marxism.Px26S.pdf Pdf.] * {{Cite journal | title = Revisits: An Outline of a Theory of Reflexive Ethnography | journal = [[American Sociological Review]] | volume = 68 | issue = 5 | pages = 645–679 | publisher = [[American Sociological Association]] | date = October 2003 | jstor = 1519757 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/Methodology/Revisits.ASR.pdf Pdf.] * {{Cite journal | title = Public Sociology: South African Dilemmas in a Global Context | journal = Society in Transition | volume = 35 | issue = 1 | pages = 11–26 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/21528586.2004.10419104 | date = 2004 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/21528586.2004.10419104 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/Society%20in%20Transition.pdf Pdf.] * "The Critical Turn to Public Sociology," pp. 309–322 in [[Rhonda Levine]] (ed.) ''Enriching the Sociological Imagination: How Radical Sociology Changed the Discipline'', New York, 2004 * {{Cite journal | title = The World Needs Public Sociology | journal = [[Norwegian Journal of Sociology]] (Sosiologisk tidsskrift) | volume = 12 | issue = 3 | pages = 255–272 | publisher = [[Universitetsforlaget]] | date = 2004 | url = https://www.idunn.no/st/2004/03/the_world_needs_public_sociology_1 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/Norway.pdf English pdf.] * "Antinomian Marxist," pp. 48–71 in Alan Sica and Stephen Turner (eds.), ''The Disobedient Generation: Social Theorists in the Sixties'' (Chicago: University of Chicago Press), 2005 * {{Cite journal | title = For Public Sociology | journal = [[American Sociological Review]] | volume = 70 | issue = 1 | pages = 4–28 | publisher = [[American Sociological Association]] | doi = 10.1177/000312240507000102 | jstor = 4145348 | date = February 2005 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/000312240507000102 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/ASA%20Presidential%20Address.pdf Pdf.] * "Provincializing the Social Sciences." pp. 508–525 in George Steinmetz (editor), ''The Politics of Method in the Human Sciences: Positivism and its Epistemological Others'' (Durhman, NC: Duke University Press), 2005 * {{Cite journal | title = The Return of the Repressed: Recovering the Public Face of U.S. Sociology, 100 Years on | journal = [[The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science]] | volume = 600 | issue = | pages = 68–87 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | date = July 2005 | jstor = 25046111 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/Annals.pdf Pdf.] * {{Cite journal | title = Public sociology vs. the market (within "''Economic sociology as public sociology''" - discussion forum) | journal = [[Socio-Economic Review]] | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 356–367 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | doi = 10.1093/ser/mwl031 | date = April 2007 | url = https://doi.org/10.1093/ser/mwl031 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS.Webpage/ps.sym.socecon.htm Burawoy's website.] [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/Socio-Economic%20Review/PS%20vs.%20Market.pdf Pdf.] * "Private Troubles and Public Issues," pp. 125–133 in [[Andrew Barlow (editor)|Andrew Barlow]] (editor), ''Collaborations for Social Justice'' (Lanham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield), 2007 * {{Cite journal | title = A Public Sociology for California | journal = [[Critical Sociology]] | volume = 34 | issue = 3 | pages = 339–348 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0896920507088162 | date = May 2008 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/0896920507088162 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/PS/A%20Public%20Sociology%20for%20California.pdf Pdf.] ==References== {{reflist}} * Burawoy, Michael, 2005, "2004 American Sociological Association Presidential address: For public sociology," ''The British Journal of Sociology'', Volume 56, Issue 2. pp. 260–290 ==External links== * [http://burawoy.berkeley.edu/ Personal website of Michael Burawoy in the University of California, Berkeley] with a lot of his books and papers in pdf-format. {{ASA Presidents|state=uncollapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burawoy, Michael}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:American Marxists]] [[Category:American sociologists]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Sociological Association]] [[Category:Marxist writers]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:University of Zambia alumni]] [[Category:World system scholars]] [[Category:1947 births]]

''Městská knihovna v Praze'' | library_logo = | image = File:Městská knihovna (Staré Město), Praha 1, Mariánské nám., Valentinská, Žatecká 1, Staré Město.jpg | image_size = | caption = Main building of the library in the [[Old Town of Prague]] (so-called ''Central Library'') | country = [[Czech Republic]] | type = [[Public library]] | scope = | established = 1891 | ref_legal_mandate = | location = [[Prague]] | coordinates = {{Coord|50|5|14.57|N|14|25|2.57|E|display=inline,title}} | branch_of = | num_branches = 40 | items_collected = [[Books]], [[magazines]], [[map]]s, [[electronic media]] | collection_size = 2,071,323 items{{cite web|title=The Library in Numbers|url=https://www.mlp.cz/en/about-us/annual-reports/annual-report-2014/the-library-in-numbers/|website=www.mlp.cz|publisher=Municipal Library of Prague|accessdate=11 January 2016}} | criteria = | legal_deposit = | req_to_access = | pop_served = General public | members = 180,508 | budget = | director = | num_employees = 480 | website = http://www.mlp.cz/en/ | phone_num = | references = }} The '''Municipal Library of Prague''' ({{lang-cs|Městská knihovna v Praze}}) is one of the largest libraries in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]]. The oldest item in the library's collections is a print of the [[Prague Bible]] from 1488. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat-inline|Městská knihovna v Praze|Municipal Library in Prague}} [[Category:Libraries in the Czech Republic]] {{Library-stub}} {{CzechRepublic-stub}}

{{Infobox Radio station | name = Radioactive FM 96 | image = Radioactive FM 96 logo.png | city = [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] | area = [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] | slogan = where the youth's at | branding = ''Radioactive FM 96'' | frequency = 96 [[MHz]] | repeater = | airdate = 13th Mar 2004 (Test transmission)
14th Oct 2004 (Official launch) | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = | power = | erp = | haat = | class = | facility_id = | coordinates = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | owner = Radioactive 96 FM | licensee = | sister_stations = | webcast = [http://www.radioactive96.fm/ra96/index.html Listen Live] | website = [http://www.radioactive96.fm/ra96/index.html Official website] | affiliations = }} '''Radioactive FM 96''' is a youth cultured radio station, broadcasting in [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]]. The radio station is owned and operated by Radioactive 96 FM Ltd. The radio station has gained immense popularity amongst the upper, upper-middle and middle class youth of Karachi. The radio is listened to not only by people in their cars, but at important youth events as well.{{cite web|title=Radioactive FM 96|url=http://www.radioactive96.fm/ra96/index.html|publisher=Radioactive FM 96|accessdate=26 June 2012}} Radioactive FM 96 portrays itself as a youth station, stating that they portray the youth culture, and are operated by the youth (a reference to its young RJ's). The radio station is funded primarily by advertisements played on air during live shown, the adverts themselves being youth related. == See also == {{Portal|Radio}} * [[List of radio stations in Pakistan]] * [[City FM 89]] * [[Radio Pakistan]] == References == {{coord missing|Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fm 100 (Pakistan)}} [[Category:Radio stations in Pakistan]] [[Category:Media in Karachi]] {{Pakistan-stub}} {{Asia-radio-station-stub}} [[ur:ایف ایم 100]]

It's based in the US, not Liberia
revision.text:
'''''The Liberian Journal''''' ('''''TLJ'''''), a major US-based [[Liberia]]n online news media, covers issues of interest to Liberians in the Diaspora, including developments in post-conflict Liberia. It also features news about Africa and many defining events around the world. Its news and information portfolio include developments in the spheres of politics, economics, sports, health, entertainment, and many other areas of human interest.
==History== Established April 8, 2008, the Minnesota-based Liberian news outfit also publishes about 15,000 free copies of monthly print newspapers.
Published and edited by Abdullah Kiatamba, a Liberian activist and writer, ''TLJ'', as it is also known, has attracted the professional skills and contributions of Liberian writers, including exiled Liberian journalists and U.S-trained news reporters and editors. ''TLJ''’s list of writers also includes Liberian scholars, professors, women leaders, activists, and a host of non-Liberians drawn from a wide range of interests.
==''The Liberian Journal'' today== ''The Liberian Journal'' has interviewed an attractive list of Liberian stakeholders, including President [[Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf]], Vice-President [[Joseph Boakai]], presidential candidate [[George Weah]], and other Liberian Diaspora leaders.
Rated as a major staple of the African ethnic media in Minnesota, ''The Liberian Journal'' is the leading Liberian media in the state, with a readership three times the size of all other emerging local news media groups combined. It has an active social network presence, especially a growing membership on both [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.theliberianjournal.com/ Official site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Liberian Journal, The}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Minnesota]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Minnesota]]
