{{Infobox summit meeting | summit_name = US–Africa Leaders Summit | other_titles = | image = US–Africa Leaders Summit Logo.png | alt = | caption = | country = [[United States]] | date = August 4–6, 2014 | motto = ''Investing in the Next Generation'' | venues = [[Mandarin Oriental, Washington, D.C.|Mandarin Oriental Hotel]]
[[White House]]
[[Harry S Truman Building]] | cities = [[Washington, D.C.]] | participants = [[Barack Obama]]
[[United States–Africa Leaders Summit#Dignitaries|50 African leaders]] {{small|(incl. 37 [[Heads of state|HOS]])}}
U.S. Business Executives | chairperson = | follows = | precedes = | website = {{URL|http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit|Official website}} | keypoints = }} The '''United States–Africa Leaders Summit''' was an international summit held in [[Washington D.C.]] from August 4–6, 2014. Leaders from fifty African states attended the three-day summit, which was hosted by U.S. President [[Barack Obama]]. The summit primarily focused on trade, investment and security of the continent.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/01/21/statement-press-secretary-announcing-us-africa-leaders-summit |title=Statement by the Press Secretary Announcing the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=21 January 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=29 January 2014}} Leaders from 50 of the 54 existing African sovereign nations were invited to attend. After the summit, the White House produced a number of Fact Sheets that summarized major outcomes. ==Background== In 2013, President Obama whilst on a [[List of presidential trips made by Barack Obama#2013|three-nation tour]] of Africa, announced his plans to host a summit of leaders from across Africa.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=30 June 2013 |title=Obama to host summit of African leaders next year |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/06/30/obama-to-host-summit-african-leaders-next-year/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=31 July 2014}} America's annual trade with the continent is about $85 billion compared to China's $200 billion.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=30 July 2014 |title=‘Cold battle’ for Africa: China’s economic interest vs. US military activity |url=http://rt.com/op-edge/176664-africa-china-us-rivalry/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[RT News]] |accessdate=31 July 2014 }} President Obama in an interview with ''[[The Economist]]'', welcomed foreign investment in the continent saying "the more the merrier" and advised African leaders to ensure that local workers benefit from the infrastructure projects and that the roads shouldn't "''just lead from the mine, to the port, to [[Shanghai]].''"{{cite news |last= |first= |date=31 July 2014 |title=The next great disruption |url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21610323-barack-obamas-ambitions-africa-will-be-measure-american-engagement |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=1 August 2014 }} On July 31, 2014 there was an On-the-Record-Conference Press Call released by the White House Office of the Press Secretary that included discussions and details of the conference. The participants were (1) [[Ben Rhodes (speechwriter)|Ben Rhodes]], Deputy National Security Advisor for Strategic Communications; (2) [[Linda Thomas-Greenfield]], Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs; and (3) [[Gayle Smith]], Senior Director for Development and Democracy at the National Security Council.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/01/record-conference-call-us-africa-leaders-summit |title=On-The-Record Conference Call for U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=August 1, 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} ==Agenda== The summit focused on [[Economy of Africa|trade and investment]] and underlined the United State's commitment to the continent's people, democracy and [[United States Africa Command|security]]. It facilitated the discussion on how to deepen these partnerships. [[United States Secretary of Commerce|US Commerce Secretary]] [[Penny Pritzker]] said that new deals worth about $900 million would be announced at the summit.{{cite news |last=Keeler |first=Dan |date=22 July 2014 |title=Obama’s Africa Summit Set to See $900m+ in Deals Announced |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/frontiers/2014/07/22/obamas-africa-summit-set-to-see-900m-in-deals-announced/ |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 July 2014 }} A number of organizations have written to President Obama to draw particular attention to the rights of [[LGBT]] Africans.{{cite web |url= http://www.globalequality.org/storage/documents/pdf/president%20barack%20obama-als-july2014.pdf |title=Letter to Obama | format= [[PDF]] |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=25 July 2014 |website=globalequality.org |publisher= |accessdate=30 July 2014}} The [[Human Rights Campaign]] and [[Human Rights First]] issued a statement urging Obama to include the discrimination against this minority in the agenda and described this summit as a 'once-in-a-generation moment' to promote equality.{{cite news |last=Crary |first=David |date=29 July 2014 |title=Activists Want Gay Rights on Africa Summit Agenda |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/activists-gay-rights-africa-summit-agenda-24763117 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[ABC News]] |accessdate=30 July 2014 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/press-release/human-rights-first-and-hrc-foundation-release-joint-report-human-rights-lgbt-africans |title=Human Rights First and HRC Foundation Release Joint Report on Human Rights for LGBT Africans |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=29 July 2014 |website= |publisher=[[Human Rights First]] |accessdate=30 July 2014}} [[Homosexuality]] is [[LGBT rights in Africa|criminalized]] in 37 Africans states. It is [[punishable by death]] in four countries: [[Mauritania]], [[Nigeria]] (states under [[Sharia in Nigeria|Sharia law]]), [[Somalia]] and [[Sudan]]; and up to [[life imprisonment]] in [[Sierra Leone]], [[Tanzania]], [[Uganda]] and [[Zambia]]. Only [[South Africa]] grants full [[Same-sex marriage in South Africa|marriage equality]] and constitutional protection against discrimination.{{cite web |url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/sites/default/files/HRF-HRC-Africa-Report.pdf |title=REPORT: THE STATE OF HUMAN RIGHTS FOR LGBT PEOPLE IN AFRICA | format = [[PDF]] |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=July 2014 |website= |publisher=[[Human Rights Campaign]] and [[Human Rights First]] |accessdate=30 July 2014}} A Program of Events was released on the White House website.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=7 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Even though the first ever U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit was held from Monday August 4 to Wednesday August 6, there were a great number of side events around the Summit.{{cite web|url=http://www.interaction.org/us-africa-leaders-summit-side-events|title=Side Events|publisher=Inter Action: A United Voice For Global Change |accessdate=7 August 2014}} On Friday '''August 1''' a Signature Event – Faith works: Honoring the contributions of the Faith Community to Peace and Prosperity in Africa took place. This included religious leaders, faith-based organization, African leaders and U.S. Government officials. The role the faith based community plays in promoting peace, prosperity and development all over Africa was discussed. The U.S.-Africa Leaders were given opportunities to contribute.{{cite web|url=http://www.mcc.gov/pages/activities/activity/us-africa-leaders-summit|title=U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Schedule of Signature Events|publisher=Millennium Challenge Corporation United States of America|accessdate=7 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214121026/https://www.mcc.gov/pages/activities/activity/us-africa-leaders-summit|archive-date=14 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} '''August 4''' Signature Events – (1) Civil Society Forum; (2) Investing in Women, Peace and Prosperity; (3) Investing in Health: Investing in Africa's Future; (4) Resilience and Food Security in a Changing Climate; and (5) Combating Wildlife Trafficking. Other events included The [[African Growth and Opportunity Act]] (AGOA) Forum which was discussed in order to pursue efforts to renew legislation.{{cite web|url=http://www.agoa.info/news/article/5479-as-use-africa-leaders-summit-begins-key-members-of-congress-say-agoa-must-be-reauthorizedl|title=As U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Begins, Key Members of Congress Say AGOA must be reauthorized |publisher=Brookings Institution Blog| date= 4 August 2014| last=Dews |first=Fred |accessdate= 7 August 2014}} A Capital Hill Reception was held by the Senate Foreign Relations and House Foreign Affairs Committees to welcome African Leaders in the afternoon. ===US–Africa Business Forum=== [[File:President Obama Delivers Remarks at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Session Three on Governing the Next Generation.jpg|thumb|Obama Delivers remarks.]] [[File:U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit AGOA Ministerial.jpg|thumb|Secretary Kerry delivering his remarks at the World Bank.]] On '''August 5''' the [[U.S. Department of Commerce]] and [[Bloomberg Philanthropies]] co-hosted the first ever U.S.-Africa Business Forum.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.org|title=U.S.-Africa Business Forum|publisher=Bloomberg Philanthropies Bloomberg.org Group| accessdate=8 August 2014}} The focus was on strengthening trade and financial ties between the United States and Africa. Good morning and welcome remarks were given by [[Penny Pritzker]], United States [[Secretary of Commerce]] and [[Michael Bloomberg]], Founder of Bloomberg Philanthropies, [[Bloomberg L.P.]] and the 108th [[Mayor of New York City]]. The Business Forum was divided into four moderated sessions. '''Session 1:''' Expanding Opportunities: The New Era For Business in Africa. Session 1 explored the U.S.-African partnerships and identified new ways to strengthen business ties and enable greater economic progress. [[Ashish J. Thakkar]], Founder and Managing Director of [[Mara Group]] welcomed the panel. [[Bill Clinton]] 42nd President of the United States and Founder of the [[Clinton Foundation]] was the Moderator. The five speakers were: [[Aliko Dangote]], President and CEO [[Dangote Group]], [[Jeff Immelt]], CEO [[General Electric]], [[Andrew N. Liveris]], President, Chairman and CEO The [[Dow Chemical Company]], [[Phuti Mahanyele]] CEO Shanduka Group and [[Doug McMillon]] President and CEO [[Walmart]] Stores Inc. Prior to the second session, remarks were given by the Chairperson of the African Union Commission, Dr. [[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]]. '''Session 2:''' Open Markets: Financing The Africa of Tomorrow. Session 2 explored the trends guiding successful and good governance in African countries, reduction of risks, strengthening investor confidence and increasing availability of U.S. capital to African and U.S. firms intending to partner on the African continent. [[Jacob J. Lew]], Secretary of the [[Treasury of the United States]] welcomed the panel. [[Donald Kaberuka]], President of the [[African Development Bank]] was the Moderator. The six speakers were: [[Ajay Banga]], President and CEO [[MasterCard]], [[Tony Elumelu]], Chairman Heirs Holdings Limited, James Mwangi, CEO [[Equity Bank]] Group, [[David Rubenstein]], CEO [[The Carlyle Group]], Sim Tshabalala, Joint CEO [[Standard Bank]] and [[Mo Ibrahim]], Founder and Chair, [[Mo Ibrahim Foundation]]. '''Session 3:''' Powering Africa: Leading Developments in Infrastructure. Session 3 explored public-private partnerships, technological innovations and financing tools that are transforming energy, transport and digital infrastructure in Africa. [[Dr. Jim Yong Kim]], President of the [[World Bank]] Group welcomed the panel. [[Susan Rice]], Assistant to the President and [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] was the Moderator. The five speakers were: [[Muhtar Kent]], Chairman of the Board, CEO [[The Coca-Cola Company]], Tshepo Mahloele CEO Harith Fund Managers, [[Strive Masiyiwa]], Founder and Chairman [[Econet Wireless]], Virginia [[Ginni Rometty]], Chairman, President and CEO of [[IBM]] and [[Stephen Schwarzman]], Chairman, CEO and Co-Founder of [[Blackstone Group|Blackstone]]. Afternoon remarks were given by [[Joseph Biden]], [[Vice President of the United States]]. '''Session 4:''' Game Plan: Shaping The Future Of A Fast-Growing Continent. Session 4 featured the African Heads of State. The assembled leaders represented the continents five regions. The discussion entailed policies that enable economic growth, intelligent infrastructure and successful private and public partnerships for the present and all the future years ahead. [[John Kerry]], [[Secretary of State of the United States]] welcomed the panel. [[Charlie Rose]] was the Moderator. The five president speakers were: [[Paul Kagame]], President of the Republic of Rwanda, [[Macky Sall]], President of the Republic of Senegal, [[Jacob Zuma]], President of the Republic of South Africa, [[Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete]], President of the United Republic of Tanzania and Mohamed [[Moncef Marzouki]], President of the Republic of Tunisia. Remarks were delivered by President Obama{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, President Obama delivers remarks|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} and Vice President Biden {{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, Vice President Biden delivers remarks to the U.S.-Africa Business Forum|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} during the U.S.-Africa Business Forum. Penny Pritzker and Michael Bloomberg co-wrote to a ''[[Forbes]]'' Opinion article where they stated that the inaugural U.S.-Africa Business Forum was expected to stimulate $14 Billion worth of business.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/08/05/obamas-u-s-africa-forum-will-catalyze-14-billion-in-business-deals/ |title=Obama's U.S.-Africa Forum Will Catalyze $14 Billion In Business Deals |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=7 August 2014}} In the evening, President Obama and the First Lady hosted a Dinner Reception at the White House for the African Leaders, government and select guests.{{cite news |last=Robertson |first=Erin C.J. |date=6 August 2014 |title=PHOTOS: Obamas Host African Leaders at a Dinner Soiree |url=http://www.theroot.com/articles/politics/2014/08/photos_obamas_hosts_african_leaders_at_a_dinner_soiree.html |publisher=The Root.com |accessdate=8 August 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809130102/http://www.theroot.com/articles/politics/2014/08/photos_obamas_hosts_african_leaders_at_a_dinner_soiree.html |archive-date=9 August 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |last=Superville |first=Darlene |date=5 August 2014 |title=Obama Welcomes African Leaders For Unusual Dinner |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/obama-hosts-white-house-dinner-for-african-leaders-24844404 |newspaper=|location= |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=8 August 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, President Obama speaks at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Dinner|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===Summit Leaders Meetings=== [[File:U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Session One.jpg|thumb|A session in progress]] [[File:President Obama Participates in the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit Family Photo.jpg|right|220|thumb|President Obama participates in a family photo with African leaders.]] On '''August 6''' the Summit Leaders Meetings took place. President Obama and African Leaders engaged in dialogue in three action-oriented sessions that addressed issues of shared common interest and mutual concern.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, President Obama Participates in the Session|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} '''Session 1''': Investing in Africa's Future – inclusive sustainable development, economic growth and trade and investment were discussed. '''Session 2''': Peace and Regional Stability – a working lunch centered around long-term solutions to regional conflict, peace keeping challenges and combating transnational threats. '''Session 3''': Governing For The Next Generation – the focus was on how to enhance governance in order to deliver services to citizens and to attract and prepare for increased domestic and foreign direct trade and investment. The Summit concluded with President Obama holding a press conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, Leader Press Conferences|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=7 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} He called the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit "an extraordinary event" {{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/obama-praises-us-africa-summit-as-an-extraordinary-success/2014/08/06/866d996a-1d8c-11e4-ae54-0cfe1f974f8a_story.html/ |title=Obama Praises U.S. Africa Summit as an 'extraordinary event'|last1=Eilperin |first1=Juliet |date=6 August 2014|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=16 August 2014}} Other events of the final day were: (1) A Spousal Program accompanied by the tag line "Investing in Our Future at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit" hosted by First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] in partnership with former First Lady, [[Laura Bush]] and the [[Bush Institute]]. This day-long spouses symposium which was held at the [[Kennedy Center]] focused on the impact of investments in education, health and public-private partnerships.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eh2WQDgBnPs |title=A Conversation With The First Lady and Mrs. Laura Bush |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2014}} The [[43rd President of the United States]], [[George W. Bush]] made an appearance, he sat with the African First Ladies and drew applause when he said "If you're worried about your husbands' political future, taking care of women is good politics." As a father and grand father he "is concerned about the future, not less" when it comes to freedom, economic empowerment and health of girls and women around the world.{{cite web|url=http://trailblazersblog.dallasnews.com/2014/08/michelle-obama-and-laura-bush-banter-and-promote-african-girls-and-women.html/ |title=Michelle Obama and Laura Bush Banter. George W. Bush joins them in promoting African girls and women |last1=Gillman |first1=Todd J. |date=6 August 2014 |publisher=Dallasnews.com |accessdate=16 August 2014}} [[Dr. Jill Biden]] delivered remarks earlier on {{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, Spousal Program|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9gv24AZ93ns|title=Dr. Jill Biden Delivers Remarks at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit |date=4 August 2014 |accessdate=16 August 2014}} and also spoke about creating opportunities for young women leaders.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rTsAUdCn4Oo |title=Dr. Jill Biden Speaks on Creating Opportunities for Young Women Leaders |date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=16 August 2014}} (2) A Dialogue with African CEO's hosted by Congressman [[Gregory W. Meeks]] and the [[Congressional Black Caucus]] Africa Task Force entailed panel discussions and networking with African business and political leaders, U.S. private sector representatives and members of congress.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|title=Program of Events, A Dialogue with African CEO's|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|date=|website=|publisher=White House|accessdate=16 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715102351/http://www.whitehouse.gov/us-africa-leaders-summit#section-program-of-events|archive-date=15 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} {{cite web|url=http://www.africastrictlybusiness.com/news-analysis/black-lawmakers-host-dialogue-african-ceos |title=Black Lawmakers Host Dialogue With African CEO's |last1=Staff |first1=AfSB |date= |website= africastrictlybusiness.com|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2014}} ==Participants== [[File:Secretary Kerry and Mauritanian President Abdel Aziz Address Reporters August 2014.jpg|thumb|Kerry with the [[Chairperson of the African Union|Chairperson]] of the [[African Union]], [[Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz|Abdel Aziz]]]] [[File:Jakaya Kikwete with Obamas 2014.jpg|thumb|Obamas with [[Tanzania]]n President [[Kikwete]] and First Lady [[Salma Kikwete]]]] Africa consists of [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Africa|54 sovereign states]]; all of them are [[Member states of the African Union|members]] of the [[African Union]]. Invitations were extended to fifty African leaders who are "in good standing" with both the US and the African Union.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=29 July 2014 |title=Washington Prepares to Host Meeting of African Leaders |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/30/us/politics/washington-prepares-to-host-meeting-of-african-leaders.html?_r=0 |newspaper=[[NY Times]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 July 2014 }} [[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]], the [[Chairperson of the African Union Commission]] was also invited.{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title= White House On U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201401220001.html |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[allafrica.com]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }}{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title= Obama to invite 47 leaders to US-Africa summit |url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/Obama-to-invite-47-leaders-to-US-Africa-summit-20140121 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[News24]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} President Obama will meet the leaders "as a group", and not on an [[Bilateralism|individual basis]].{{cite news |last=Wonacott |first=Peter |date=21 July 2014 |title=Obama Charts a Risky Course With Africa Heads-of-State Summit |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/frontiers/2014/07/21/obama-charts-a-risky-course-with-africa-heads-of-state-summit/ |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 July 2014 }}{{cite news |last=Akande |first=Laolu |date= |title=U.S-Africa Summit: Obama Rules Out Meeting With Jonathan, Others |url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/lead-story/171600-u-s-africa-summit-obama-rules-out-meeting-with-jonathan-others |newspaper=[[The Guardian (Nigeria)]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 July 2014 }} Of the fifty leaders, thirty-seven were [[Heads of State]].{{cite Reason |- | {{ALG}} || President [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]]{{cite web |url=http://www.chathamhouse.org/expert/comment/15414 |title=The First US-Africa Summit: More than a Birthday Party for President Obama |last1=Vines |first1=Alex |last2= |first2= |date=1 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[Chatham House]] |accessdate=6 August 2014}} || health reasons |- | {{ANG}} || President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] || |- | {{BWA}} || President [[Ian Khama]]{{cite news|last=|first=|date=5 August 2014|title=Botswana’s Khama misses US-Africa Leaders Summit|url=http://en.starafrica.com/news/botswanas-khama-misses-us-africa-leaders-summit.html|newspaper=|location=|publisher=en.starafrica.com|accessdate=6 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808042607/http://en.starafrica.com/news/botswanas-khama-misses-us-africa-leaders-summit.html|archive-date=8 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} || |- | {{EGY}} || President [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]]{{cite news |last= |first= |date= 23 July 2014|title=Why did Sisi decline Obama's invitation to Washington? |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/analysis/2014/07/23/Why-did-Sisi-decline-Obama-s-invitation-to-Washington-.html |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Al Arabiya News |accessdate=6 August 2014 }} || |- | {{LBR}} || President [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]]{{cite news |last= |first= |date=31 July 2014 |title=Two African Leaders Skip Obama Summit to Deal With Ebola |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-07-31/two-african-leaders-skip-obama-summit-to-deal-with-ebola |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Bloomberg Business Week |accessdate=31 July 2014 }} || due to an [[2014 West Africa Ebola outbreak|Ebola outbreak]] |- | {{MAR}} || King [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI]]{{cite news |last= |first= |date=3 August 2014 |title=King Mohammed VI Absent From US-Africa Summit |url=http://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2014/08/135895/king-mohammed-vi-absent-from-us-africa-summit/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Morocco World |accessdate=6 August 2014 }} || |- | {{SLE}} || President [[Ernest Bai Koroma]]{{cite news |last= Boyer |first=Dave |date=31 July 2014 |title=3 African leaders cancel trip to U.S. over Ebola outbreak; Obama still plans summit |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jul/31/african-leader-cancels-trip-us-over-ebola-outbreak/ |newspaper=Washington Times |location= |publisher= |accessdate=31 July 2014 }} || due to an Ebola outbreak |- | {{ZMB}} || President [[Michael Sata]] || health reasons |- | {{flag|Cote d'Ivoire}} || President [[Alassane Ouattara]]|| |} {{End}} ===Exclusions=== *{{CAF}} – interim President [[Catherine Samba-Panza]] was not invited as her country is currently [[Member states of the African Union#Suspension|suspended]] from the [[African Union]] (AU) following the [[2013 Central African Republic coup d'état|2013 coup d'état]]. An election will be held in February 2015.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=28 July 2014 |title=Uninvited To U.S. -Africa Leaders Summit: CAR’s Catherine Samba-Panza |url= http://afkinsider.com/66006/uninvited-catherine-samba-panza-tries-bring-together-central-african-republic/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=afkinsider.com |accessdate=30 July 2014 }}{{youtube|91Mz6kQGQ9M|Obama administration may revise the list of African leaders invited to US summit}} *{{ERI}} – President [[Isaias Afwerki]] was excluded and the White House cited the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1907|UN sanction]] on the country and its refusal to accept full [[Eritrea–United States relations|diplomatic relations]] with the U.S.{{cite news |last=Pecquet |first=Julian |date=22 January 2014 |title=Obama excludes Egypt, six others from Africa summit |url=http://thehill.com/policy/international/196128-obama-excludes-egypt-six-others-from-africa-summit |newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate=27 July 2014 }} *{{flag|Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic}} ([[Western Sahara]]) – President [[Mohamed Abdelaziz (Sahrawi politician)|Mohamed Abdelaziz]] was omitted as the U.S. does not [[International recognition of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic|recognize]] his country.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=January 2014 |title=Obama's U.S.-Africa Summit – Who's In, Who's Out |url=http://allafrica.com/view/group/main/main/id/00028610.html?aa_source=slider-cat-1-12 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[allafrica.com]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} *{{SUD}} – President [[Omar al-Bashir]] was excluded as he is [[List of people indicted in the International Criminal Court|indicted]] at the [[International Criminal Court]], which also issued an arrest warrant for him. The Department of State lists Sudan as one of the [[state sponsors of terrorism]]. The Sudanese government criticized its exclusion. The Deputy Speaker disagreed with the U.S. stance on her country.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=26 January 2014 |title=Sudan criticises its exclusion from US-Africa summit |url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article49735 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[Sudan Tribune]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} *{{ZIM}} – A U.S. official{{who|date=August 2014}} was reported to have said that President [[Robert Mugabe]] was not invited because he is currently on the list of the [[Specially Designated Nationals]].{{cite news |last= |first= |date=27 January 2014 |title=US-Africa summit: Why Mugabe was snubbed |url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/Zimbabwe/US-Africa-summit-Why-Mugabe-was-snubbed-20140127 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[News24]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} Information Minister [[Jonathan Moyo]] dismissed the summit as a "non-event" saying that the U.S. was afraid of China.{{cite news|last=|first=|date=27 January 2014|title=Zimbabwe not concerned by Washington snub: official|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2014-01/27/c_133078789.htm|newspaper=|location=|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|accessdate=29 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140131080653/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/africa/2014-01/27/c_133078789.htm|archive-date=31 January 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Mugabe's spokesman, [[George Charamba]], was quoted to have said that they were not bothered as the "world is larger than America."{{cite news |last= |first= |date=23 January 2014 |title=Obama shuts out Mugabe |url=https://www.newsday.co.zw/2014/01/23/obama-shuts-mugabe/ |newspaper= |location= |publisher=Newsday |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} ;Temporary At the time of the announcement of the summit in January 2014, the following three states were suspended from the [[African Union]] due to their political situation. They have since been re-admitted following the restoration of democracy and rule of law: *{{EGY}} – was suspended from the AU following the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|2013 coup d'état]]. The Egyptian Foreign Ministry spokesman stated that this decision was "wrong and short-sighted".{{cite news |last= |first= |date=22 January 2014 |title=Egypt Says Not Invited to US Africa Summit |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/egypt-invited-us-africa-summit-21622066 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[ABC News]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} Following the successful [[Egyptian presidential election, 2014|presidential election]] in May 2014, the US extended a late invite.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=14 July 2014 |title=U.S. offers Egypt late invite to Africa summit |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/07/14/U-S-offers-Egypt-late-invite-to-Africa-summit-in-Washington-.html |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |accessdate=30 July 2014 }} *{{GNB}} – was suspended following the [[2012 Guinea-Bissau coup d'état|2012 coup d'état]] [[Guinea-Bissau general election, 2014|Election]] was held in April 2014. *{{MAD}} – at the time the invitations were sent out, the country was suspended because of the [[2009 Malagasy coup d'état|2009 coup d'état]]. On 28 January 2014, the AU lifted its sanctions following the successful [[Malagasy general election, 2013|election]]{{cite news |last= |first= |date=28 January 2014 |title=US urges Madagascar leader to gain population 'confidence' |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5imxn4JFN0rXoJLvPpp4_ZTF6X_dQ?docId=72e55970-7eea-4f44-a711-e670bd7c8b44 |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |accessdate=29 January 2014 }} ==Controversies== The list of invited leaders included the following [[List of current longest ruling non-royal national leaders|long serving]] African [[Strongman (politics)|strongmen]]:https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/where-is-human-rights-in-the-africa-summit/2014/08/02/858d7eae-18ee-11e4-9e3b-7f2f110c6265_story.html{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Jeffrey |date=3 July 2014 |title=Obama should embrace Africa’s democratic standard-bearers |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/7/us-africa-summitbarackobamaforeignpolicydemocracytradeinvestment.html |newspaper= |location= |publisher= Aljazeera|accessdate=1 August 2014 }} {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | background color = | width = 180 | image1 = Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo with Obamas 2014.jpg | image2 = Blaise Compaoré with Obamas 2014.jpg | image3 = Yahya Jammeh with Obamas 2014.jpg | footer_align = center | footer = Obama with [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo#Abuses|Nguema]], [[2014 Burkinabé uprising|Compaoré]] and [[Yahya Jammeh#Criticism|Jammeh]]. }} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Country !! Leader !! In power since |- | {{ANG}} || [[José Eduardo dos Santos]] || align=center|1979 |- | {{BUR}} || [[Blaise Compaoré]] || align=center|1987 |- | {{CMR}} || [[Paul Biya]] || align=center|1982 |- | {{CGO}} || [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]] || align=center|1997 |- | {{GNQ}} || [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]] || align=center|1979 |- | {{GAM}} || [[Yahya Jammeh]] || align=center|1994 |- | {{UGA}} || [[Yoweri Museveni]] || align=center|1986 |} [[Human Rights Watch]] and EG Justice called upon the US to denounce [[Equatoguinean]] President [[Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo]]'s [[Human rights in Equatorial Guinea|human rights]] abuses in his country.{{cite web |url= https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/07/30/equatorial-guinea-halt-prisoner-torture |title=Equatorial Guinea: Halt Prisoner Torture |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=30 July 2014 |website= |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |accessdate=31 July 2014}} The [[Economic Freedom Fighters]], a South African opposition party, objected to the exclusion of Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe; it also disagreed with Morocco's inclusion as it continues to [[Moroccan occupation of Western Sahara|"illegally" occupy]] [[Western Sahara]].{{cite web |url= http://effighters.org.za/eff-rejects-the-us-africa-leadership-summit/ |title=EFF rejects the US-AFRICA leadership summit |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=30 July 2014 |website= |publisher=[[Economic Freedom Fighters]] |accessdate=31 July 2014}} ==Outcome== President Obama delivered a personal, six-minute toast at the U.S.-Africa Summit Dinner in which he invoked his African heritage, saying, “I stand before you as the president of the United States and a proud American. I also stand before you as the son of a man from Africa. The blood of Africa runs through our family. And so for us, the bonds between our countries, our continents, are deeply personal.”{{cite news|last1=Topaz|first1=Jonathan|title=Obama's Africa toast gets 'personal'|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/08/obama-toast-slavery-africa-leaders-summit-109754.html|accessdate=6 August 2014|publisher=Politico|date=6 August 2014}} He announced $20 billion of investment in energy projects in sub-Saharan Africa.{{cite news|title=Africa: USAID Announcements At the African Leaders' Summit for Tuesday, August 5th|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201408061563.html|accessdate=6 August 2014|publisher=AllAfrica|date=5 August 2014}} Through the Office of The Press Secretary, the White House released a number of Fact Sheets pertaining to the outcome of the United States–Africa Leaders Summit. On August 4, 2014, FACTSHEET: Investing in African Trade for Our Common Future was released. It clarified strategies pertaining to the renewal and update of the African Growth Opportunities Act (AGOA), synergies through aligning assistance, improving infrastructure to enhance competitiveness, strengthen trade capacity and creation of new African markets.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-investing-african-trade-our-common-future |title=FACTSHEET: Investing in African Trade for our Common Future |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} On August 5, 2014, FACTSHEET: The Doing Business in Africa Campaign (DBIA) was released. The emphasis was on the United States' commitment to strengthen its ties and commercial relationship with Africa. The Fact Sheet clarified this new commitment to expand the Doing Business in Africa Campaign: "At today’s U.S.-Africa Business Forum, President Obama announced $7 billion in new financing to promote U.S. exports to and investments in Africa under the DBIA Campaign. U.S. companies announced new deals in clean energy, aviation, banking, and construction worth more than $14 billion, in addition to $12 billion in new commitments under the President’s Power Africa initiative from private sector partners, the World Bank, and the government of Sweden. Taken together, these new commitments amount to more than $33 billion, supporting economic growth across Africa and tens of thousands of U.S. jobs." In addition, the Fact Sheet emphasized the President's Executive Order to create a Presidential Advisory Council on DBIA and new U.S. Government resources to support U.S. exports and investments in Africa.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/05/fact-sheet-doing-business-africa-campaign |title=FACTSHEET: Doing Business in Africa Campaign |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=5 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} Other Materials, Outcomes and Fact Sheets directly related to the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit were: (1) U.S.-Africa Cooperation in Advancing Gender Equality {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-african-cooperation-advancing-gender-equality |title=FACTSHEET: U.S.-Africa Cooperation Advancing Gender Equality |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (2) U.S.-African Cooperation on Global Health{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-african-cooperation-global-health |title=FACTSHEET: U.S.-African Cooperation on Global Health |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (3) Shared Investment in Youth {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-shared-investment-youth |title=FACTSHEET: Shared Investment in Youth |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (4) U.S.-African Cooperation on Food Security {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-african-cooperation-food-security |title=FACTSHEET: U.S.-African Cooperation on Food Security |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (5) U.S. Engagement on Climate Change and Resilience in Africa {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-engagement-climate-change-and-resilience-africa |title=FACTSHEET: U.S. Engagement on Climate Change and Resilience in Africa |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (6) U.S. Support for Democratic Institutions, Good Governance and Human Rights in Africa {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-support-democratic-institutions-good-governance-and-human- |title=FACTSHEET: U.S. Support for Democratic Institutions, Good Governance and Human Rights in Africa |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (7) U.S. Support for Combating Wildlife Trafficking {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/04/fact-sheet-us-support-combating-wildlife-trafficking |title=FACTSHEET: U.S. Support for Combating Wildlife Trafficking |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=4 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (8) Powering Africa: Increasing Access to Power in Sub-Saharan Africa {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/05/fact-sheet-powering-africa-increasing-access-power-sub-saharan-africa |title=FACTSHEET: Powering Africa: Increasing Access to Power in Sub-Saharan Africa |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=5 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (9) Investments Announced at Symposium for African Spouses Hosted by First Lady Michelle Obama and Former First Lady Laura Bush. "More than $200 million committed to programs that will empower more than 1 million people in Africa." {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/06/investments-announced-symposium-african-spouses-hosted-first-lady-michel |title=Investments Announced at Symposium for African Spouses Hosted by First Lady Michelle Obama and Former First Lady Laura Bush |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (10) U.S. Support for Peacekeeping in Africa {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/06/fact-sheet-us-support-peacekeeping-africa |title=FACTSHEET: U.S. Support for Peacekeeping in Africa |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (11) Security Governance Initiative {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/06/fact-sheet-security-governance-initiative |title=FACTSHEET: Security Governance Initiative |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} (12) Partnering to Counter Terrorism in Africa {{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/06/fact-sheet-partnering-counter-terrorism-africa |title=FACTSHEET: Partnering Counter Terrorism in Africa |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} The White House Press Office released a Statement by the Chair of the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit. Topics covered were the Summit's Background; Investing in Africa's Future; Advancing Peace and Regional Stability; Governing for the Next Generation; Investing in Women for Peace and Prosperity; and, Providing Skills and Opportunities to the Youth. In closing, it was duly noted that President Obama announced that the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit would be a recurring event.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/08/06/statement-chair-us-africa-leaders-summit|title=Statement by the Chair of the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=6 August 2014 |website= |publisher=[[White House]] |accessdate=31 August 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Sister project links | wikt=no | commons= Category:U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit | b=no |q=no | n=no |s=no | v=no | voy=no | species=no |d=Q17149480| display=US-Africa Leaders Summit}} *[http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/africa-in-focus/posts/2014/01/23-africa-leaders-summit-kimenyi United States-Africa Leaders’ Summit: Seizing the Opportunity to Reposition Africa-U.S. Relations] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-07-28/obama-bids-to-forge-african-ties-as-china-becomes-first-choice.html Obama Seeks Closer Africa Ties as China Is First Choice] * [http://www.ipsnews.net/2014/07/human-rights-low-on-u-s-africa-policy-summit/ Human Rights Low on U.S-Africa Policy Summit] ;Images * {{Flickr-inline2|photos/statephotos/sets/72157646159301566/|White House Dinner}} * {{Flickr-inline2|photos/statephotos/sets/72157645873058602/|Second Day}} {{International fora on Africa}} {{DEFAULTSORT:United States-Africa Leaders Summit}} [[Category:United States–African relations]] [[Category:Politics of Africa]] [[Category:Diplomatic conferences in the United States]]
